profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T18:32-0400

did.abstract:
Born to a Welsh father and Niska mother of high status, William Beynon was raised in Victoria, B.C., speaking both Niska and English. A member of the Wolf (Laxgibu) phratry, he became an hereditary Tsimshian chief in 1914 upon the death of his maternal uncle, and a year later, began to work with the anthropologist C. Marius Barbeau, collecting narratives and artifacts. During the mid- to late-1930s, Beynon worked closely with Franz Boas, providing him with an extensive series of narratives and translations from the Tsimshian.
The Beynon Papers includes a series of correspondence between Beynon and Franz Boas, 1933-1937, along with a small number of narratives in Tsimshian with interlinear English translations. The letters complement, but do not overlap with those in the Boas Papers.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Winter, Barbara J., "William Beynon and the anthropologists," Canadian Journal of Native Studies 2 (1984), 279-292.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The Franz Boas Papers (B B61) include 65 letters, bills, or receipts relating to Beynon's work with Boas, 1936-1941. Beynon is also mentioned in Boas' correspondence with Viola Garfield and Marius Barbeau.

A microfilm of the extensive collection of William Beynon Tsimshian Manuscripts (Film 1416) at Columbia University is available for consultation at the APS. These are the manuscripts referred to in Beynon's correspondence with Boas.

Several narratives collected by Beynon are located in the collection of the American Council of Learned Societies Committee on Native American Languages, including his "Ethnographic and folkloric texts of the Tsimshian" (no. 35; Freeman and Smith 3771), "Tsmishian Kinship terms" (Pn5a.2, Freeman and Smith 3776) and "Tsimshian word list" (Pn5a.3; Freeman and Smith 3777). Additional material collected by Beynon is found in three of C. Marius Barbeau's reports to the APS Phillips Fund Committee, "The Gwenhoot of Alaska" (Freeman and Smith 3767), "Temlar'ham"(Freeman and Smith 3769), and "Wolf clan invaders from the northern plateau..." (Freeman and Smith 3770).

The other main sources for manuscripts collected by Beynon are Columbia University and the Canadian Centre for Folk Cultural Studies at the National Museum of Man, Ottawa. A portion of the English texts at Columbia have been published by the Metlakatla Indian Community in multiple volumes as Tsimshian Stories.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Beynon manuscripts were once held by Irving Goldman, and were transferred to the APS in September 2002 (M2002-30).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: William Beynon Papers, American Philosophical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A small collection consisting of both correspondence and ethnographic texts with interlinear English equivalents, the papers of the Tsimshian ethnographer and field assistant William Beynon are a useful addition to the study of the cultures of the Northwest Pacific Coast. From Boas's first, tentative interest in discovering a new field assistant to his eager encouragement to record additional narratives (for a price), the collection also provides an interesting view onto the mediation between an anthropologist and his ethnographic subject.

The letters both to and from Boas chart the development of the relationship between the two, giving detailed information on Beynon's field plans and the steady stream of manuscripts sent back to New York. More valuable than the correspondence, perhaps, is a series of texts recorded, transcribed and (in most cases) translated by Beynon. Among these are two copies of manuscripts that were apparently previously collected by Henry W. Tate, and the first four manuscripts sent east by Beynon. At least two other manuscripts appear to show Boas's efforts to correct (or, at least, understand) Beynon's orthography.

Two additional items of later provenance have found their way into the collection: a 1940 letter from Ella Cara Deloria to Boas, informing him of her new address, and a manuscript by the anthropologist Irving Goldman discussing Boas's ethnographic work on the Kwakiutl (Kwakwaka'wakh).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Born to a Welsh father and Niska mother of high status, William Beynon was raised in Victoria, B.C., speaking both Niska and English. A member of the Wolf (Laxgibu) phratry, Beynon was schooled in some of the traditional responsibilities of a hereditary Tsimshian chief, however he later wrote that when he first traveled to Prince Rupert in 1914 to perform rites associated with the funeral of his maternal uncle, a chief of the wolf phratry, he felt that he was insufficiently knowledgeable about the rituals and obligations of being a chief. Only reluctantly was he persuaded to accept the title he inherited from his uncle, adopting his uncle's name, Gusgain. His status was no doubt enhanced among the coastal Tshimshian by his marriage to a niece of Tsibase, chief of Kitkatla.

During C. Marius Barbeau's first season in the field, 1915, Beynon signed on as a field assistant and translator, beginning what would become a forty year association with anthropologists and linguists. Through Barbeau, he became familiar with Viola Garfield and Edward Sapir, and in 1936, began an intense association with Franz Boas. Working for canneries in the summer months, Beynon avidly pursued ethnographic work at other times of the year, often working for more than one client at a time and, according to Barbeau, occasionally selling material more than once. Following in the shoes of Henry W. Tate and George Hunt, Beynon organized expeditions to both coastal and inland Tsimshian villages, soliciting informants and recording, translating, and interpreting (in more than one sense) texts, rituals, and material culture. Speaking both Nass and Gitksan dialects, he was as productive as he was valuable in describing Tsimshian society, describing secret (and illegal) potlatch ceremonies, and , amassing a remarkable trove of narratives, many of which have yet to be published.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommended to Boas for his interest in Tsimshian narratives by Viola Garfield, Edward Sapir and Marius Barbeau.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is interested in pursuing Tsimshian stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing account of the holder of the chief name Nieswexs took his place. Terms for providing texts. Differences between Tsimshian villages, informants.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will write about proposed work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Beynon's price is more than he can afford. Sending a copy of a manuscript by Henry Tate, which should be rewritten in proper style.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Negotiation on compensation for work. Has begun work on four short manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending on of Tate's manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending more of Tate's manuscripts dealing with the adventures of the Gispaxlot's tribes and Legex..

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Very interested in Beynon's stories and the price is not excesive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggests he spend not more than $50 a month for Boas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for payment and books. Enclosing manuscripts 5 and 6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Boas collected the tale of Dzagagilac in 1888 and 1900.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing manuscripts 7-10, synopses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes clarification on writing several words.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Understands that there must be several stories about the origins of the four societies (phratries).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing manuscripts 11-14, synopses. Offers services at Hartley Bay and Kitamat, which he will visit in December or January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much to be done in Gitamat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending manuscripts from Tate's work. Has secret societies stories importaed from the southern tribes into the northern.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending more of Tate's work. Tate's difficult style.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending more Tate material. Odd story of hermaphrodite, for which he had seen a reference when he was on the Nass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: It has been a long time since he has heard Tsimshian, but there are some things about which he is doubtful in Beynon's work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Re: compensation for work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concentrating on Tate's material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent money. Cannot raise the monthly total for informants to $75.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending $32.70.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Representing spelling of Tsimshian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing manuscript 34, the last of Tate's, and 35-39, synopses. Manuscript 39: "It was an elaborite affair staged in a moderbn atmosphere. Even the food served was entirely white man's food in the manner of the white man. The Chief himself was a half-breed with a splendid education and a very bright man in public life, with little or no knowledge of his Native antecedents having been raised in the south in the city of Victoria. But the older people created the atmosphere for the festivity which was very impressive. Ther distribution of ealth to the guests took the form of money presents."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Could come to New York. Still studying Boas's grammatical questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Completing a new series of Hartley Bay stories. Social organization amongthe coastal tribes: Halait groups may be more important and less variable than clans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the Halait manuscript. Studies of the Halait.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 45-48, including continuation of the Halait material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear plans for the visit have fallen through. Asks for prompter remittances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending manuscripts 49-53 and bill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remitting manuscripts 59-63. Working with three informants to standardize phonetic spelling and pronunciation: the best informants in his and Viola Garfield's view.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Manuscripts 64-68; synopses. Asks again for sufficient sum each month for informants and whether there has been improvement in his phonetics. Itemized invoice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Manuscripts 69-74, synopses. Itemized invoice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry he would not advance him money, but will take Boas's offer of advance of $25 for Kitkatla and Skeena River villages. Hopes for advance to cover informant expenses during summer field work among the Gitksan, Gitselasu, and Kitzemgelelm. Understands from Garfield that nothing has been done in Gitksan; Beynon speaks both Gitksan and Nass dialects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Main informant is an excellent one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 80-86. Itemized invoice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 97-104. Attempting to record the myth 'Am'ala, which Boas wanted. Hopes to be able to provide a full account of Gitksan potlatches in the winter. The Gitksan have retained their old ways better than most Tsimshians since their hunting territories are about their only asset and because they have a sympathetic Indian agent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 114-118, including account of elevation of Ginax'engik chiefs. Has recorded a Tsimshian version of Lagabula from informant who had worked by Henry Tate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires a description of the objects used in the Halait, particularly the meaning of a tube open at both ends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 119-122, synopses. Legex.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information on Halaits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 123-126.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 127-129. Leaving next month for the Skeena canneries and will get material, particularly Lagabula narrative. Will also try to get Gitksan material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 130-133. Sing two new informants, Harry Brooks and William Henry Pierce. Has recorded the story of how a woman cohabited with a dog from an elderly woman who gave a version that included the "embarrassing scenes" omitted by Pierce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 139-145.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Survey for the Forestry Dept. has been delated by weather. Secret societies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 152-158.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chief Tsiba-sa of Kitkatla has died at 98. "The writer as a chief of the Wolf clan was visited by messengers that had beensent out by the Kitkatlas to invite all of the Tsimshian chiefs and their spokesmen. I made a complete record of all the events... Even though I lived in Prince Rupert the delgatio[n] came to my residence very early in the morning and as soon as they entered they sang a dirge song and gave me my ground hog gift which notified myt that there was a royal death at Kitkatla..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Working the death and ceremont of Tsibasa; none of the older type of speech heard twenty years ago.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscripts 175 and 176. Looking into Boas's question of the origin of royal groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding manuscript on royal status. Certain that Hartley Bay and Kitamat are the best places to study halait; "The difficulty with Port Simpson informants is that the religious contacts made with them has resulted in their almost total loss of past knowledge concerning the halait."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending her address.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invoices.

did.unittitle: Originals of TLsS to William Beynon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: BRITTLE: HANDLE ONLY WITH CARE.

did.unittitle: Manuscript 1. Gid'astsu (Klemtu). Phratryal Peculiarities among the Gidastsu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tsimshian with interlinear English.

did.unittitle: Manuscript 1. Phratrial peculiarities among the Gid'astsu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In English.

did.unittitle: Manuscript 2. Origin name he.l gitxala. Account of the arrival of the first white man

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In Tsimshian with interlinear English. Marginal notes, added in red in unknown hand.,

did.unittitle: Manuscript 2. Origin name He.l, Gitxala, also an account of the arrival of the first white man

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informant: George McCankey

did.unittitle: Manuscript 3. The myth of Nugu.n'aks: Gid'astsu. Myth ofthe house of Temks... and all its subdivisions among the Tsimsyen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In Tsimshian with interlinear English. Marginal notes, added in red in unknown hand. "All of these houses on the different groups of people use this myth in connection with their myth of origin and crests and dirge and nursery songs." Related by James Robinson, age 70.

did.unittitle: Manuscript 4. Retaliation of animals, or the extinction of the Gitwalksabe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In Tsimshian with interlinear English. Marginal notes, added in red in unknown hand. Informant Benjamin Tate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In Tsimshian with English translation.

did.unittitle: Melska wala wileksam wildogita dzimsyen dil gidaganitz

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed narrative with interlinear transcription in different Tsimshian orthography.

did.unittitle: Melska wal wileksam wildogit tsimsyen dil gidaganit and Melsgam waldogitga Haida dil gispaxlats

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incomplete narratives with interlinear English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incomplete narrative with interlinear English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incomplete narrative with interlinear English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tsimshian words with English equivalents.

did.unittitle: "The words you selected and the way in which I mean them"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes first page (mutilated) of "The history of great war between..."; partial inventory of Beynon manuscripts; 4 cards with Tsimshian and English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paper given at symposium, Fifty Years Later: The Legacy of Franz Boas, held at Barnard College, 1992.
